title: We have no plans to cause mayhem during Fire Festival – NDC youth
text:
Source: Ghana | Joy News | Hashmin Mohammed Date: 22-10-2015 Time: 08:10:09:pm File photo 
A Tamale-based youth group of the National Democratic Congress, the Aluta Boys have dismissed reports in the media claiming they had planned to use Friday’s Fire Festival in Tamale to create confusion in reaction to the release of five NPP youth activists. 
A court of Appeal in Kumasi on Wednesday freed the five NPP activists — Yahuza Yakubu, Majeed Alhassan, Habib Mohammed Dagbana and Shaibu Alhassan - who were sentenced to various terms imprisonment after a clash in Tamale which led to the death of Rashid Alhassan, a youth activist of the NDC. 
But the NDC youth group in a meeting Thursday morning with the Youth Organizers of the NDC and NPP in the Northern Region dismissed any plans to cause confusion in the Tamale metropolis. 
They described the reports as mischievous and called on Ghanaians to disregard the media reports. 
The NPP was led by its Regional Youth organizer Alhaji Rashid COP whiles the NDC team was lead by the Deputy National Youth organizer Kobby Balon. The group was highly impressed about the meeting involving the leadership of the two main political parties. 
Vice Chairman of the group Alhassan Jamal called for continuous dialogue between the NPP and NDC in order to foster unity and partnership that can alleviate poverty in the Northern Region. 
Alhassan Jamal however appealed to government to ensure that their friends who are in prison custody over violence-related allegations are freed. 
NPP Northern Regional Youth organizer Alhaji Rashid COP admonished: "We are all one. Politics shouldn’t divide us. Let's foster unity among ourselves. Poverty should be our enemy not political opponents”. 
The Deputy National Youth Organizer of the NDC Kobby Balon called on the Youth to take advantage of government interventions for the youth to engage themselves in useful activities. 
BACKGROUND TO THE ISSUE 
The Tamale High Court presided over by Justice Lawrence Mensah in 2013, sentenced a youth activist of the opposition New Patriotic Party, Yakubu Yahuza, to death by hanging. He was found guilty of murder and conspiracy to murder. Four other activists of the party Abibu Dagbana, Majeed Alhassan, Alhassan Sayibu and Imoro Gundaana, were also convicted for conspiracy to murder and where to serve 36 years in prison. The decision was a unanimous one taken by a seven-member jury. The five were arrested in February 2009 following a political clash between NPP and NDC youth in Tamale, resulting in the death of Rashid Alhassan, a youth activist of the NDC. Several houses, vehicles and motorbikes and other valuables properties in Gumbihini, Choggu and other surrounding communities in the Tamale metropolis were also set ablaze.
